narratives.evidence_quote: According to top Kremlin propagandists, it’s only a matter of time before the West admits its defeat and pays reparations to Moscow or risks a devastating nuclear strike.
narratives.reasoning: This quote directly evokes fear of a nuclear strike as a consequence for the West not submitting to Russian demands, fitting the definition of amplifying war-related fears.

narratives.evidence_quote: Russian state media and government officials have taken to describing any opponents of the Kremlin in Ukraine as or “Banderites,” the followers of Stepan Bandera... This expression is being used as indiscriminately as branding all opponents the “Nazis.”
narratives.reasoning: The text describes the Russian state media's practice of indiscriminately labeling Ukrainian opponents as 'Banderites' or 'Nazis,' which is a tactic to undermine the legitimacy and character of Ukrainians resisting the invasion.

narratives.evidence_quote: Appearing on a state TV show Sunday Evening With Vladimir Soloviev, political scientist and Professor of Communications Dmitry Evstafiev argued: “Right now, President Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin’s third proposal to the Ukrainian leadership is on the table. This, of course, is a demonstration of his greatest respect and—I would even say—of love by our President towards the Ukrainian people.”
narratives.reasoning: This quote frames Putin's actions as stemming from 'greatest respect' and 'love,' which is a positive, glorifying portrayal of Russia's leader and his intentions.

narratives.evidence_quote: Matveychev noted: “There isn’t a single country in the world that is as easily manipulated as America.”
narratives.reasoning: This statement directly criticizes and undermines the United States by portraying it as gullible and easily controlled, which fits the narrative of discrediting the West.

narratives.narrative_name: URW: Negative Consequences for the West
narratives.evidence_quote: He argued: “Here’s what will be on the table after our victory... The dissolution of NATO, because the presence of NATO in some countries is getting in our way. Extradition of all war criminals... like [Anton] Herashchenko... Zelensky, [former President of Ukraine Petro] Poroshenko. Extradition of various oligarchs... We should be thinking about reparations from the damage that was caused by the sanctions and the war itself... The return of all Russian properties, those of the Russian empire, the Soviet Union and current Russia, which has been seized in the United States, and so on.”
narratives.reasoning: This extensive list details severe, punitive demands and consequences (dissolution of NATO, reparations, seizure of property) that Russia intends to impose on the West following a victory, highlighting negative outcomes for Western interests.

narratives.evidence_quote: “Here’s what will be on the table after our victory... After Ukraine’s demilitarization is completed... we’re going to raise the stakes... I think we should start voicing all of that, so they understand what will be on the table.”
narratives.reasoning: The speaker is making detailed predictions and assumptions about the potential results and consequences of the conflict, specifically outlining post-victory demands, which aligns with the narrative of speculating on war outcomes.

subnarratives.subnarrative_name: URW: Amplifying war-related fears: There is a real possibility that nuclear weapons will be employed
subnarratives.evidence_quote: According to top Kremlin propagandists, it’s only a matter of time before the West admits its defeat and pays reparations to Moscow or risks a devastating nuclear strike.
subnarratives.reasoning: This quote directly evokes fear of a nuclear strike as a consequence if the West does not submit to Russian demands, fitting the definition of amplifying fears about nuclear weapon use.

subnarratives.subnarrative_name: URW: Amplifying war-related fears: There is a real possibility that nuclear weapons will be employed
subnarratives.evidence_quote: On Monday, Soloviev revisited the topic of nuclear blackmail... He said: “I still think that those who took our money should be told, you have 24 hours to unfreeze our funds, or else we’ll send you what you know we’ve got. Your choice. Tactical or strategic, take a pick.”
subnarratives.reasoning: This is a direct threat of nuclear attack (tactical or strategic) issued as blackmail, explicitly amplifying fears about the employment of nuclear weapons.

subnarratives.subnarrative_name: URW: Amplifying war-related fears: Russia will also attack other countries
subnarratives.evidence_quote: Matveychev nodded: “That was my next point. As well as the Antarctic... We discovered it, so it belongs to us...”
subnarratives.reasoning: The claim of territorial ownership over Alaska and Antarctica, presented as a post-victory demand, implies expansionist ambitions beyond Ukraine, supporting the subnarrative that Russia will attack or make claims on other countries.

subnarratives.evidence_quote: The segment was entitled “Denazification of Ukraine—the new opportunities for growth” and appeared to serve as a tool to desensitize the Russian population for the grotesque war trials and executions the Kremlin is reportedly planning to conduct in Ukraine...
subnarratives.reasoning: This describes the normalization of plans for public executions and war trials in Ukraine, which amplifies war-related fears through the depiction of extreme brutality and a dehumanizing campaign, supporting the parent narrative but not fitting the other specific definitions.

subnarratives.subnarrative_name: URW: Discrediting Ukraine: Ukraine is associated with nazism
subnarratives.evidence_quote: She alleged: “To the dismay of the State Department, it turned out that Americans are indifferent towards saving Ukrainian Banderites.” Russian state media and government officials have taken to describing any opponents of the Kremlin in Ukraine as or “Banderites,” the followers of Stepan Bandera, the ultranationalist political figure... This expression is being used as indiscriminately as branding all opponents the “Nazis.”
subnarratives.reasoning: The quote explicitly uses the term 'Banderites' to label Ukrainian opponents, linking them to a historical figure associated with ultranationalism, and the text clarifies this is used as a synonym for 'Nazis,' directly supporting the subnarrative of associating Ukraine with Nazism.

subnarratives.subnarrative_name: URW: Discrediting Ukraine: Ukraine is a puppet of the West
subnarratives.evidence_quote: In the surreal world of Russian state television, Russia is about to prevail in its war against Ukraine, which is being presented as a battle against the United States and NATO.
subnarratives.reasoning: This framing presents the conflict not as a war between Russia and Ukraine, but as a proxy battle where Ukraine is merely a front for the United States and NATO, implying Ukraine lacks sovereignty and is controlled by Western powers.

subnarratives.subnarrative_name: URW: Discrediting Ukraine: Discrediting Ukrainian government and officials and policies
subnarratives.evidence_quote: Extradition of all war criminals... like [Anton] Herashchenko [former deputy minister at the Ukrainian Ministry of Internal Affairs], Zelensky, [former President of Ukraine Petro] Poroshenko.
subnarratives.reasoning: The quote lists current and former high-ranking Ukrainian officials, including President Zelensky, as 'war criminals' to be extradited, which is a direct and aggressive attempt to delegitimize and criminalize the Ukrainian government and its leadership.

subnarratives.subnarrative_name: URW: Praise of Russia: Praise of Russian President Vladimir Putin
subnarratives.evidence_quote: “Right now, President Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin’s third proposal to the Ukrainian leadership is on the table. This, of course, is a demonstration of his greatest respect and—I would even say—of love by our President towards the Ukrainian people.”
subnarratives.reasoning: The quote directly praises Putin's actions as stemming from 'greatest respect' and 'love' for the Ukrainian people, presenting his leadership in a positive and benevolent light.

subnarratives.subnarrative_name: URW: Praise of Russia: Russia is a guarantor of peace and prosperity
subnarratives.evidence_quote: “Right now, President Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin’s third proposal to the Ukrainian leadership is on the table. This, of course, is a demonstration of his greatest respect and—I would even say—of love by our President towards the Ukrainian people.”
subnarratives.reasoning: The framing of Putin's negotiation proposals as acts of 'love' and 'respect' portrays Russia (through its leader) as a benevolent actor seeking a peaceful resolution, aligning with the narrative of Russia as a guarantor of peace.

subnarratives.subnarrative_name: URW: Praise of Russia: Russia has international support from a number of countries and people
subnarratives.evidence_quote: “There isn’t a single country in the world that is as easily manipulated as America.”
subnarratives.reasoning: This statement, while criticizing the US, implies a broader global perspective where Russia is not isolated and can outmaneuver its primary adversary, suggesting a position of strength and implied support in the international arena.

subnarratives.evidence_quote: “We can take them down without it.” (in response to a question about using nuclear strikes)
subnarratives.reasoning: This statement supports the parent narrative by portraying Russia as militarily superior and confident enough to achieve its goals against the West without resorting to its ultimate weapons, which is a form of praise for Russian capability that doesn't fit the more specific subnarrative definitions.

subnarratives.subnarrative_name: URW: Discrediting the West, Diplomacy: The West is weak
subnarratives.evidence_quote: Multiple state TV shows emphasized the reluctance on the part of the United States and NATO to intervene against Russia’s bloody invasion of its neighbor, presenting it as the proof that the Kremlin can go to any lengths to emerge victorious.
subnarratives.reasoning: This quote frames the West's (U.S. and NATO) reluctance to directly intervene militarily as proof of weakness, suggesting the Kremlin can act with impunity because the West lacks the potency or will to stop it.

subnarratives.subnarrative_name: URW: Discrediting the West, Diplomacy: The West does not care about Ukraine, only about its interests
subnarratives.evidence_quote: She alleged: “To the dismay of the State Department, it turned out that Americans are indifferent towards saving Ukrainian Banderites.”
subnarratives.reasoning: This direct quote claims that the American public is indifferent to Ukraine's fate, implying Western support is not driven by genuine concern for Ukraine but by other, likely self-serving, interests of the State Department.

subnarratives.subnarrative_name: URW: Discrediting the West, Diplomacy: The West is overreacting
subnarratives.evidence_quote: Olga Skabeeva, the host of a state TV show 60 Minutes, intentionally distorted the statements of White House press secretary Jen Psaki. On Friday, Skabeeva claimed: “Jennifer Psaki’s statement said that no matter what Putin does in Ukraine—whether he uses biological weapons or drops a nuclear bomb—the United States won’t get involved.”
subnarratives.reasoning: By fabricating a claim that the U.S. said it wouldn't intervene even if Russia used WMDs, the narrative suggests the West's actual reaction (sanctions, support) is disproportionate and hysterical, as Russia's actions (framed as a 'special operation') supposedly do not warrant such a response.

subnarratives.subnarrative_name: URW: Discrediting the West, Diplomacy: Other
subnarratives.evidence_quote: Matveychev noted: “There isn’t a single country in the world that is as easily manipulated as America.”
subnarratives.reasoning: This quote supports the parent narrative of discrediting the West by portraying the United States as gullible and easily controlled, which is a manipulative communication pattern that undermines Western credibility but does not fit neatly into the other specific subnarrative definitions provided.

subnarratives.subnarrative_name: URW: Negative Consequences for the West: Sanctions imposed by Western countries will backfire
subnarratives.evidence_quote: "We should be thinking about reparations from the damage that was caused by the sanctions and the war itself, because that too costs money and we should get it back."
subnarratives.reasoning: This quote directly frames Western sanctions as causing damage to Russia, for which Russia will demand financial reparations from the West, implying the sanctions will ultimately cost the West money.

subnarratives.subnarrative_name: URW: Negative Consequences for the West: Other
subnarratives.evidence_quote: "According to top Kremlin propagandists, it’s only a matter of time before the West admits its defeat and pays reparations to Moscow or risks a devastating nuclear strike."
subnarratives.reasoning: This statement supports the parent narrative of negative consequences for the West by presenting a catastrophic ultimatum: the West must either pay reparations (a financial/political negative consequence) or face nuclear war (an existential negative consequence). This goes beyond the specific 'sanctions backfire' or 'refugee flows' subnarratives.

subnarratives.subnarrative_name: URW: Speculating war outcomes: Russian army is collapsing
subnarratives.evidence_quote: Russian President Vladimir Putin’s willingness to negotiate with the President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelensky is being packaged as a sign of his love and good will, and not the consequence of mounting losses and humiliating defeats faced by the Russian military in Ukraine.
subnarratives.reasoning: This quote directly states that the Russian military is facing 'mounting losses and humiliating defeats,' which aligns with the definition of suggesting a significant decline in its effectiveness and strength.

subnarratives.evidence_quote: In the surreal world of Russian state television, Russia is about to prevail in its war against Ukraine... According to top Kremlin propagandists, it’s only a matter of time before the West admits its defeat and pays reparations to Moscow or risks a devastating nuclear strike.
subnarratives.reasoning: This quote speculates on the outcome of the war, predicting a Russian victory and Western defeat/concessions. It supports the parent narrative of speculating war outcomes but does not fit the specific definitions of army collapse or losing territories; it is a broader, speculative claim about the conflict's end result.
